column2:

column2:
Over time, you've created 5 snapshots of a single instance. To save space, you delete snapshots
number 3 and 4. What has happened to the fifth snapshot?
column3:
The data from both snapshots 3 and 4 necessary for continuance are
transferred to snapshot 5.
column4: It is no longer useable and cannot restore data.
column5: All later snapshots, including 5, are automatically deleted as well.
column6:
The data from snapshot 4 necessary for continuance was transferred to snapshot 5,
however snapshot 3's contents were transferred to snapshot 2.

One of the customer needs to store time series data in Google Cloud Platform. They have found Big
Table to be a natural fit for time series data . Choose the best practise suggested by Google Cloud for
schema design patterns for storing time series in Cloud Bigtable.
column3: For row key design pattern ,use tall and narrow tables
column4:
For row key Always for a row key for a time series includes a timestamp, make sure
all your writes will target a single node; fill that node; and then move onto the next
node in the cluster
column5:
Prefer reverse timestamps only where your most common query is for the latest
values
column6:
For patterns for column design , in general ,keep row sizes below
approximately 100 MB
column7: Design your row key with your queries in mind .

You want to enable your running Google Container Engine cluster to scale as demand for your

column3:
Add additional nodes to your Container Engine cluster using the following
command: gcloud container clusters resize CLUSTER_NAME --size 10
column4:
Add a tag to the instances in the cluster with the following command: gcloud

column5:
Update the existing Container Engine cluster with the following command:
gcloud container clusters update CLUSTER_NAME --enable-autoscaling --minnodes=
l --max-nodes=10
column6:

container clusters create CLUSTER_NAME --enable-autoscaling --min-nodes=l --
max-nodes=10 and redeploy your application

column2:
The application reliability team at your company has added a debug feature to their backend service
to send all server events to Google Cloud Storage for eventual analysis
The event records are at least 50 KB and at most 15 MB and are expected to peak at 3,000 events per
second. You want to minimize data loss. Which process should you implement?
column3:
Append metadata to file body. Compress individual files. Name files with a
random prefix pattern. Save files to one bucket
column4:
Batch every 10,000 events with a single manifest file for metadata. Compress event
files and manifest file into a single archive file. Name files using serverName-
EventSequence. Create a new bucket if bucket is older than 1 day and save the
single archive file to the new bucket. Otherwise, save the single archive file to
existing bucket.
column5:
Compress individual files. Name files with serverName-EventSequence. Save files to
one bucket Set custom metadata headers for each object after saving.
column6:
Append metadata to file body. Compress individual files. Name files with
serverName-Timestamp. Create a new bucket if bucket is older than 1 hour and save
individual files to the new bucket. Otherwise, save files to existing bucket
column9: Google cloud Certified Professional cloud Architech

column2:
For this question, refer to the TerramEarth case study.
To speed up data retrieval, more vehicles will be upgraded to cellular connections and be able to
transmit data to the ETL process. The current FTP process is error-prone and restarts the data transfer
from the start of the file when connections fail, which happens often. You want to improve the
reliability of the solution and minimize data transfer time on the cellular connections. What should you
do?
column3:
Use multiple Google Container Engine clusters running FTP servers located in
different regions. Save the data to Multi-Regional buckets in US, EU, and Asia. Run
the ETL process using the data in the bucket
column4:
Directly transfer the files to a different Google Cloud Regional Storage bucket
location in US, EU, and Asia using Google APIs over HTTP(S). Run the ETL
process to retrieve the data from each Regional bucket.
column5:
Use one Google Container Engine cluster of FTP servers. Save the data to a Multi-
Regional bucket. Run the ETL process using data in the bucket.
column6:
Directly transfer the files to different Google Cloud Multi-Regional Storage bucket
locations in US, EU, and Asia using Google APIs over HTTP(S). Run the ETL process
using the data in the bucket.
column9: Google cloud Certified Professional cloud Architech

column2:
What is the best practice for separating responsibilities and access for production and development
environments?
column3:
Separate project for each environment, each team only has access to their
project
column4: Separate project for each environment, both teams have access to both projects.
column5: Both environments use the same project, but different VPC's.
column6:
Both environments use the same project, just note which resources are in use by
which group.

column2:
Your developer currently maintains a J2EE application. What two considerations should he consider
for moving his application to the cloud to meet demand and minimize overhead? (Choose two)
column3: Host resources in Cloud Bigtable.
column4: Configure application for Cloud Dataproc
column5: Re-tooling the application to run on App Engine.
column6: Re-tool to run on managed instance group with appropriate storage backend.

column2:
You work in a small company where everyone should be able to view all resources of a specific
project. You want to grant them access following Google’s recommended practices. What should you
do?
column3:
Create a script that uses "gcloud projects add-iam-policy-binding" for all users’
email addresses and the Project Viewer role.
column4:
A. Create a script that uses "gcloud iam roles create" for all users’ email addresses
and the Project Viewer role.
column5:
Create a new Google Group and add all users to the group. Use "gcloud
projects add-iam-policy-binding" with the Project Viewer role and Group email
address.
column6:
Create a new Google Group and add all members to the group. Use "gcloud iam
roles create" with the Project Viewer role and Group email address.
column9: Google cloud Certified Professional cloud Architech

column2:
One of your primary business objectives is being able to trust the data stored in your application. You

authenticity of your logs?
column3: Create a JSON dump of each log entry and store it in Google Cloud Storage.
column4: Write the log concurrently in the cloud and on premises.
column5: Digitally sign each timestamp and log entry and store the signature.
column6: Use an SQL database and limit who can modify the log table.

column4: gsutil mb -c coldline gs://archive_bucket
column5: gsutil mb -c nearline gs://archive_bucket

Dress4Win is evaluating how their current database structure would translate to Google Cloud. They

column2:
To set up a virtual private network between your office network and Google Cloud Platform and have

column2:
You need to deploy an update to an application in Google App Engine. The update is risky, but it can

column3:
Deploy a new version of the application but use traffic splitting to only direct a

column4: Deploy the application temporarily and be prepared to pull it back if needed
column5:
Warn users that a new app version may have issues and provide a way to contact

column6:
Create a new project with the new app version, then redirect users to the new
version.

column2: How are subnetworks different than the legacy networks?
column3: They're the same, only the branding is different.
column4:
Each subnetwork controls the IP address range used for instances that are
allocated to that subnetwork.
column5: With subnetworks IP address allocation occurs at the global network level.
column6: Legacy networks are the preferred way to create networks.

Remove the external IP address and have remote employees dial into the company

column4:
Use parallel uploads to break the file into smaller chunks then transfer it

Cloud Deployment Manager only supports automation of Google Cloud

column2:
Your developer group works on a set of VM's frequently throughout the day. To save costs, you

column3: Set the disk to no-auto-delete to preserve contents
column4: Back up the disk contents to Cloud Storage before deleting.
column5: When not in use, only stop the instance instead of deleting it.
column6: Take a snapshot of the disk before terminating the VM.

column3:
You must create a new node pool in the same cluster and migrate the workload
to the new pool
column4: gcloud container clusters update mycluster --machine-type n1-standard-4
column5: This action is not possible
column6: gcloud container clusters resize mycluster --machine-type n1-standard-4

You're writing a Python application and want your application to run in a sandboxed managed

Your marketing department wants to send out a promotional email campaign. The development team

column3:
Use a single compute Engine virtual machine (VM) to host a web server, backed by

column4:
Use a Google Container Engine cluster to serve the website and store data to

column5:
Use a managed instance group to serve the website and Google Cloud Bigtable to
store user data.
column6:
Use Google App Engine to serve the website and Google Cloud Datastore to
store user data.

column3: Org viewer, project owner
column4: Org viewer, project viewer
column5: Org admin, project browser

Using the principle of least privilege, your colleague Bob needs to be able to create new instances on

column3: Give Bob Compute Engine Instance Admin Role for Project A
column4: Give Bob Compute Engine Admin Role for Project A.
column5: Create a shared VPC that Bob can access Compute resources from.
column6: Give Bob Project Editor IAM role for Project A.

column6: Create IAM Folders to manage groups of projects

column2:
Using principal of least privilege and allowing for maximum automation, what steps can you take to

column3: Create account for auditors to have view access to Stackdriver Logging.
column4: Export audit logs to Cloud Storage via an export sink.
column5: Export audit logs to BigQuery via an export sink.
column6:
Create account for auditors to have view access to export storage bucket with
the Storage Object Viewer role.

column2:
If external auditors need to be able to access your admin activity logs once a year for compliance,
what is the best method of preserving and sharing that log data? (Choose two)
column3:
If they need access to multiple logs in a single bucket, and they have a GCP
account, export logs to a Cloud Storage bucket for long-term retention and
grant auditor accounts the Storage Object Viewer role to the bucket.
column4:
Create GCP accounts for the auditors and grant the Project Viewer role to view logs
in Stackdriver Logging
column5:
If they do not need a GCP account and need to view a single date's object,
export the logs to a Cloud Storage bucket for long-term retention and generate
a signed URL for temporary object-level access.
column6: Export logs to Cloud Storage bucket and email a list of the logs once per year.
column9: Google cloud Certified Professional cloud Architech

column2:
Your application needs to process credit card transactions. You want the smallest scope of Payment

column3:
Create separate subnetworks and isolate the components that process credit card
data.
column4:
Streamline the audit discovery phase by labeling all of the virtual machines (VMs)
that process PCI data.
column5: Create separate projects that only process credit card data.
column6:
Enable Logging export to Google BigQuery and use ACLs and views to scope
the data shared with the auditor.
column7: Create a tokenizer service and store only tokenized data.

column6: Google Cloud SQL

column2:
Your company has decided to make a major revision of their API in order to create better experiences

column3: Configure a new load balancer for the new version of the API
column4: Reconfigure old clients to use a new endpoint for the new API.

column6: Use separate backend pools for each API path behind the load balancer.

column2:
You are running an application in Google App Engine that is serving production traffic. You want to

column3: Deploy the new application version temporarily, and then roll it back.

Set up a second Google App Engine service, and then update a subset of clients to
hit the new service
column6:
Deploy a new version of the application and use traffic splitting to send a small
percentage of traffic to it.

column2:
Your company's user-feedback portal comprises a standard LAMP stack replicated across two zones.
It is deployed in the us-central1 region and uses autoscaled managed instance groups on all layers,
except the database. Currently, only a small group of select customers have access to the portal. The
portal meets a 99.99% availability SLA under these conditions. However next quarter, your company
will be making the portal available to all users, including unauthenticated users. You need to develop
a resiliency testing strategy to ensure the system maintains the SLA once they introduce additional
user load. What should you do?
column3:
Expose the new system to a larger group of users and increase group’s size each
day until autoscale logic is triggered on all layers. At the same time, terminate
random resources on both zones.
column4:
Create synthetic random user input, replay synthetic load until autoscale logic
is triggered on at least one layer, and introduce "chaos" to the system by
terminating random resources on both zones.
column5:
Capture existing users input and replay captured user load until autoscale is
triggered on all layers. At the same time, terminate all resources in one of the zones.
column6:
Capture existing users input and replay captured user load until resource utilization
crosses 80%. Also, derive estimated number of users based on existing users’ usage
of the app, and deploy enough resources to handle 200% of expected load.
column9: Google cloud Certified Professional cloud Architech

column2:
Dress4Win wants to do penetration security scanning on the test and development environments

Notify Google to begin conducting regular penetration security scanning on behalf

column4:
Deploy the security scanners into the cloud environments and conduct penetration
testing within each environment.
column5:
Use the on-premises scanners to conduct penetration testing on the cloud
environments routing traffic over the VPN.
column6:
Use the on-premises scanners to conduct penetration testing on the cloud
environments routing traffic over the public internet.

column5:

Create a snapshot of each VM prior to an update and recover the VM from the

column2:
A production database virtual machine on Google Compute Engine has an ext4-formatted persistent
disk for data files. The database is about to run out of storage space. How can you remediate the
problem with the least amount of downtime?
column3:
In the Cloud Platform Console, increase the size of the persistent disk and use

column4:
Shut down the virtual machine, use the Cloud Platform Console to increase the

column5:
In the Cloud Platform Console, increase the size of the persistent disk and verify the

column6:
In the Cloud Platform Console, create a new persistent disk attached to the virtual

column7:
In the Cloud Platform Console, create a snapshot of the persistent disk, restore the
snapshot to a new larger disk, unmount the old disk, mount the new disk, and restart
the database service.

column5:
Use Storage Transfer Service to transfer the offsite backup files to a Cloud Storage
Regional storage bucket as a final destination.
column6:
Use Storage Transfer Service to transfer the offsite backup files to a Cloud Storage
Multi-Regional storage bucket as a final destination.
column9: Google cloud Certified Professional cloud Architech

column2:
You are designing a relational data repository on Google Cloud to grow as needed. The data will be
transactional consistent and added from any location in the world. You want to monitor and adjust
node count for input traffic, which can spike unpredictably. What should you do?
column3:
Use Cloud Spanner for storage. Monitor storage usage and increase node count if
more than 70% utilized.
column4:
Use Cloud Spanner for storage. Monitor CPU utilization and increase node
count if more than 70% utilized for your time span.
column5:
Use Cloud Bigtable for storage. Monitor data stored and increase node count if more
than 70% utilized.
column6:
Use Cloud Bigtable for storage. Monitor CPU utilization and increase node count if
more than 70% utilized for your time span
column9: Google cloud Certified Professional cloud Architech

column2:
You need to create a new Kubernetes Cluster on Google Cloud Platform that can autoscale the
number of worker nodes. What should you do?
column3:
Create a cluster on Kubernetes Engine and enable autoscaling on Kubernetes
Engine.
column4:
Create a cluster on Kubernetes Engine and enable autoscaling on the instance
group of the cluster.
column5:
Configure a Compute Engine instance as a worker and add it to an unmanaged
instance group. Add a load balancer to the instance group and rely on the load
balancer to create additional Compute Engine instances when needed.
column6:
Create Compute Engine instances for the workers and the master and install
Kubernetes. Rely on Kubernetes to create additional Compute Engine instances
when needed.
column9: Google cloud Certified Professional cloud Architech

column2:
Your development team has installed a new Linux kernel module on the batch servers in Google
Compute Engine (GCE) virtual machines (VMs) to speed up the nightly batch process. Two days after
the installation, 50% of the batch servers failed the nightly batch run. You want to collect details on the
failure to pass back to the development team. Which three actions should you take? Choose 3
answers
column3:
Identify whether a live migration event of the failed server occurred, using in
the activity log.
column4: Use Stackdriver Logging to search for the module log entries
column5:
Use gcloud or Cloud Console to connect to the serial console and observe the
logs.
column6: Read the debug GCE Activity log using the API or Cloud Console.
column7:
Export a debug VM into an image and run the image on a local server where kernel
log messages will be displayed on the native screen.
column9: Google cloud Certified Professional cloud Architech

column2:
Your company runs several databases on a single MySQL instance. They need to take backups of a
specific database at regular intervals. The backup activity needs to complete as quickly as possible
and cannot be allowed to impact disk performance. How should you configure the storage?
column3:
Mount additional persistent disk volumes onto each virtual machine (VM) instance in
a RAID10 array and use LVM to create snapshots to send to Cloud Storage.
column4:
Configure a cron job to use the gcloud tool to take regular backups using persistent
disk snapshots.
column5:
Mount a Local SSD volume as the backup location. After the backup is
complete, use gsutil to move the backup to Google Cloud Storage.
column6:
Use gcsfuse to mount a Google Cloud Storage bucket as a volume directly on the
instance and write backups to the mounted location using mysqldump
column9: Google cloud Certified Professional cloud Architech
